content: The "Distracted Driving Prevention Act of 2013" includes sections on short title, table of contents, distracted driving prevention, research program, and FCC report on distracted driving technology. The "Distracted Driving Prevention Act of 2013" adds a new section to Chapter 4 of title 23, United States Code, regarding distracted driving prevention. It includes provisions for withholding funds from states that do not have or enforce distracted driving laws meeting specific requirements. The "Distracted Driving Prevention Act of 2013" adds a new section to Chapter 4 of title 23, United States Code, regarding distracted driving prevention. It includes provisions for withholding funds from states that do not have or enforce distracted driving laws meeting specific requirements, such as prohibiting texting while driving and establishing fines for violations. The "Distracted Driving Prevention Act of 2013" imposes fines for violations of laws prohibiting handheld cell phone use while driving, with increased penalties for repeat offenses and accidents caused by device use. The law prohibits holding a cell phone for calls while driving, allows hands-free devices for calls, and makes violations a primary offense. The "Distracted Driving Prevention Act of 2013" imposes fines for violations of laws prohibiting handheld cell phone use while driving, with increased penalties for repeat offenses and accidents caused by device use. The law also requires distracted driving issues to be tested as part of the driver's license examination, establishes minimum fines for violations, and provides increased penalties for accidents caused by drivers using a personal wireless communications device. Exceptions are allowed for contacting emergency services. The "Distracted Driving Prevention Act of 2013" imposes fines for violations of laws prohibiting handheld cell phone use while driving, with increased penalties for repeat offenses and accidents caused by device use. Exceptions are allowed for contacting emergency services, activating hands-free functionality, and emergency services personnel using devices while on duty. Withheld funds from non-compliant states remain available for apportionment for up to three fiscal years. If a state enacts and enforces a law meeting requirements, withheld funds will be apportioned to the state. The apportioned funds remain available for expenditure for up to three fiscal years. In this section, if a state fails to enact or enforce a law meeting requirements, withheld funds will lapse at the end of the period. The definition of "driving" is clarified as operating a motor vehicle on a public road. The term 'hands-free device' allows a driver to use a personal wireless communications device without holding it. A 'personal wireless communications device' is a device for transmitting personal wireless services, excluding a global navigation satellite system receiver for positioning or navigation. The term 'texting' refers to manually entering data into a personal wireless communications device for electronic data communication purposes. SEC. 3. RESEARCH PROGRAM for distracted driving prevention. The Secretary of Transportation will establish a research program within 180 days to study distracted driving by passenger and commercial vehicle drivers. The program will focus on driver behavior, vehicle technology, and portable electronic devices commonly used in vehicles. Research contracts may be granted to non-governmental entities for this purpose. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress on the research program studying distracted driving by vehicle drivers, focusing on behavior, technology, and portable electronic devices. The Federal Communications Commission must provide a report to Congress within 180 days of this Act's enactment, detailing data collection on distracted driving with wireless devices, technologies to reduce distractions, and available authority to address the issue.
